document_data.name: Malachite
document_data.mainbody: '''Malachite''' was an [[Ornamental stones|ornamental stone]] related to [[azurite]] and often used in inexpensive jewelry.
document_data.Description: Malachite was distinguished by its green stripes of many shades. Striking in appearance and inexpensive, these ornamental stones were usually tumbled smooth or cut [[wikipedia:cabochon|cabochon]] and polished for jewelry among those that could not afford fancier gems.
document_data.Usage:
Flecks of malachite were used by the [[hag]] [[Auntie Ethel]] in the creation of the ''[[Heart of Stone]]'' potion. The concoction offered significant protection against all manner of [[poison]].

[[Halfling]] pottery from [[Luiren]] created between [[750 DR]] and [[830 DR]] was known to be intricately decorated with malachite and [[lapis]]. This was somewhat unusual as hin preferred functionality to decoration.
document_data.Powers: Malachite was a spell component for some [[Divine magic|divine]] spells of the [[elemental sphere]] and [[arcane]] spells that dealt with cold, heat, ice, or fire. It was crushed into powder for use in magical immersions for items that promoted warmth, cold resistance, or fire resistance.
document_data.Rumors and Legends: Malachite was reputed to prevent falls and therefore was often used on devices like ''[[Ring of feather falling|rings of feather falling]]'' as part of the adornment. However, this was just catering to public demand because malachite had no gravitational intervention powers.
document_data.Trivia:
* Malachite was a common stone among the drow, a gem worn by drow of the average station. They only used blue-green though.
* The [[lesser deity]] [[Iyachtu Xvim]] was known to occasionally send malachite gems to show favor or inspire his followers.
* Malachite was especially favored by Druids for its color and beauty.
* Some adventurers used malachite to identify certain dangerous substances, as it easily bubbled and dissolved in acid.
* Artists were known to crush malachite into dust to use it as a pigment.
* In [[Faer√ªn]], parents sometimes put malachites under pillows of kids believing it warded off nightmares.
